title: 107_hr5351
content: The "Investment Incentives Act of 2002" increases the limitation on capital losses of individuals against ordinary income. The amendment raises the limit from $3,000 to $20,000 and from $1,500 to $10,000. This change applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Additionally, the Act accelerates the increase in contributions to certain retirement plans. The "Investment Incentives Act of 2002" raises the deductible amount for IRAs to $5,000 and adjusts the inflation rates for 2002 and 2001. For 401(k) Plans, the limitation is increased to $15,000. The "Investment Incentives Act of 2002" raises the deductible amount for IRAs to $5,000 and adjusts the inflation rates for 2002 and 2001. For 401(k) Plans, the limitation is increased to $15,000. In addition, section 457(b)(2) of the Code is amended to set the applicable dollar amount to $15,000 for 457 Plans. The Secretary will adjust the $15,000 limit for 401(k) Plans for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002, following the same rules as section 415(d). Any increase not a multiple of $500 will be rounded down. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. SEC. 4. EXEMPTION OF CERTAIN INTEREST AND DIVIDEND INCOME FROM TAX. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for partial exclusion of dividends and interest received by individuals. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code excludes dividends and interest received by individuals from gross income, with a maximum exclusion of $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). Certain dividends from tax-exempt corporations are not eligible for this exclusion. Capital gain dividends from regulated investment companies and real estate investment trusts are also not included in this exclusion. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code excludes dividends and interest received by individuals from gross income, with a maximum exclusion of $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). Certain dividends from tax-exempt corporations are not eligible for this exclusion. Capital gain dividends from regulated investment companies and real estate investment trusts are also not included in this exclusion. For treatment of capital gain dividends, see sections 854(a) and 857(c). In the case of a nonresident alien individual, the exclusion only applies for taxes imposed under sections 871(b)(1) and 877(b). Dividends from employee stock ownership plans are not covered by this exclusion. Conforming amendments include changes to section 32(c)(5) of the Code regarding interest and dividends received. The Internal Revenue Code excludes interest and dividends received by individuals from gross income under section 116. Amendments are made to sections 32(i)(2) and 86(b)(2) to account for this exclusion. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to coordinate with the exclusion of interest and dividends under section 116. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code coordinate with the exclusion of interest and dividends under section 116. Dividends or interest received by the common trust fund are considered as received by the participant. Amendments include the inclusion of dividends or interest excluded from gross income and restrictions applicable to dividends received from Real Estate Investment Trusts. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code coordinate with the exclusion of interest and dividends under section 116. Dividends received from Real Estate Investment Trusts meeting certain requirements are not considered as dividends for tax purposes. Amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code under section 116 partially exclude dividends and interest received by individuals. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 2001.
